awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed activity is the completion of the I-Corp program by the team of Marshall Van Alstyne (PI), Dawei Shen (entrepreneurial lead), and Robert Lloyd (mentor). Based on prior NSF grant 0925004, Van Alastyne and Shen have studied effects of knowledge markets on information sharing and worker productivity within firms. Empirical research suggests that provision of knowledge markets to workers can have large positive effects on the productivity. They have also created Barter, a prototype knowledge market that has been successfully used in classroom settings at several universities to enhance student learning. The intellectual contribution is to use economic theory to optimize crowdsourcing.  Over the course of the I-Corp program, Van Alstyne, Shen, and Lloyd will validate the company business model in light of early customer feedback while completing a prototype commercial product based on the successful academic prototype. A prototype customer relationship with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia has already been established and discussions are underway with other potential enterprise customers.

Organizations have sought gains through knowledge sharing for more than 50 years, implementing suggestion boxes, intranets, share drives, and now social wikis. Despite significant global investments, firms have had difficulty coaxing participation, efficiently generating new ideas, and accurately valuing those ideas. Techniques to successfully perform these tasks have the potential to broadly increase information access and dramatically increase commercial productivity. Based on an empirical study of a Japanese bank, the team found that one standard deviation increase in use of a knowledge market improved worker productivity by 10%. The National Bureau of Economic Research and European Economic Association peer reviewed these results. The World Bank has also asked to use the team's tools. Economists broadly argue that knowledge production is a key factor in worker productivity, which in turn is a major driver of wages and economic growth. If the team can replicate even a small portion of these results on a large scale, it could have an enormous positive impact on US and world economic welfare.

Review of the Project and its Major Goals

 

The primary goal of the I-Corps program was to develop commercialization plans for our research on knowledge markets using the lean-startup methodology. We proposed to build and commercialize a software platform with a set of knowledge tracking and trading methods to facilitate information sharing, price that information, and boost productivity inside organizations. Algorithms are based on Nobel-prize winning economics as well as new statistical methods that we developed.  Such a system is capable of providing the following services from a technological and functional standpoint:

 

  • The value of information or innovation contributed by users is recognized and counted using “credits”, a type of currency in the system;
  • The system is able to track information reuse, and give credits back to original sources;
  • Knowledge marketplaces allow users to exchange information or services and efficiently map experts to problems;
  • Managers of the system can stimulate or curate information-sharing activities by employing economic tools, such as controlling the issuance of credits, and running “campaigns”.

 

Such a “knowledge economy” is aimed at addressing the following critical challenges faced by organizations, especially in the domain of collaboration, knowledge sharing, and innovation:

 

  • Members may need incentives to share information because they are not recognized properly;
  • Inefficient allocation of human resources to problems firms must tackle;
  • Suboptimal productivity and business outcomes can be improved by promoting collaboration, decentralized innovation and information sharing.

 

Summary of Research Activities and Results

 

I-Corps Workshop and Building Commercialization Plan

 

The team worked extensively to produce a solid commercialization plan, attending Steve Blank’s NSF workshop, undergoing training, working with potential customers, investors, industry veterans, and advisors to explore customer pain points, and how our technology could deliver tangible value. We interviewed hundreds of people and dozens of senior executives of various organizations. In addition, the team has held joint workshops with top executives from firms such as Coca Cola, General Electric, and Firmenich, to demonstrate our research and technology, and explore collaboration possibilities.

 

Research & Development

 

I-Corps funding also helped the team advance its research and software development. We developed a functional prototype, “Barter”, which implements a knowledge exchange supported by credits, market rules, managerial tools, and advanced tracking functions. The software well achieves the purposes of demonstration and piloting with interested organizations.
